author: pietjepuk
content: I think that post is about a PBS world, where the builders are indeed required to have more powerful hardware. That is decoupled from the validator entity though. A builder can still be a validator if they want, and run it on the same hardware. Just that not _every_ validator is expected to have powerful hardware to build blocks/store all history/state/etc.

author: ctrl_alt_lulz
content: ^ I think eventually there will reach a point where specialization will need to happen just due to the increased system complexity of increasing scalability since web3 is really trailing web2 (it's just a lot harder to scale in web3), I think the hard thing would possibly be how you manage the balance eg if we needed a specialized validator, how do you keep that from being run by centralized entities and making sure enough of them are online

author: pietjepuk
content: Well, that is what PBS is all about isn't it? Embracing the centralizing effects of block building, and enshrining in into the protocol with safeguards against censorship and the like.

author: ctrl_alt_lulz
content: I think it's all about acceptable tradeoffs that overall result in a better ecosystem for everyone. i think a good model of validator split could be something like 30% solo operators, maybe 30% pooled dex operators, and maybe 40% centralized operators, that way there's enough architecture diversity to make the network even more stable overall

author: pietjepuk
content:
I very much disagree that that is a good validator split, but that's more of a personal value than anything else. I would say that Ethereum is generally more of a "we want more decentralization" type of community. What are the technical merits to a large percentage of centralized validators?

If this ties in to your earlier discussion about computing requirements for validators, then I still have the following suggestions (assuming you haven't done so already):
1) Gather data on the usage as it scales with # of validator per node
2) Do clients differ on their resource usage?
3) Talk to client teams to see if there is anything that can be done to lower requirements/increase efficiency for high numbers of validators (i.e. reduce duplicate work).
